Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Time-series Characterization and Modeling of Non-model Microalgae at the Systems-level for Sustainable Chemical Production

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI Name: Gunes E. Atilla-Gokcumen
Number: 1438172

One of the grand challenges of engineering in the 21st century is to provide sustainable and economically-viable commodity products while easing the pressure of population increase, global climate change, and limited natural resources. One plausible approach is to utilize renewable feedstocks that can accommodate these many criteria in long-term adaption and mitigation strategies. Towards this end, microalgae can efficiently convert sunlight and carbon dioxide into high-value products such as biofuels, nutritional supplements, and therapeutic agents. However, the global cellular metabolic processes underlying biofuel and sustainable chemical production from microalgae are not well understood. This project will develop fundamental and applied engineering tools and metrics to better understand how photosynthetic organisms can be exploited to produce high-value products with applications in energy, health, and food industries. The theme of sustainable fuel and chemical production through microalgae-based processes has compelling broad societal impacts, and these topics will be communicated through academic and civic engagement activities that are integrated with the proposed research.

Technical Description

In microalgae, several complex and linked internal mechanisms dictate hydrocarbon biosynthesis, degradation, and, ultimately, the prospect for their accumulation. In fact, preliminary data suggests stress conditions such as nutrient deprivation in microalgae not only trigger lipid and terpenoid biosynthesis but also up-regulate several enzymes responsible for lipid degradation in lysosomes and peroxisomes. The relationship between the expression and interaction of anabolic and catabolic reactions will be investigated with the goal of maximizing hydrocarbon formation that will extend the current understanding of hydrocarbon biosynthesis in microalgae. More specifically, in order to maximize carbon dioxide fixation efficiency and lipid and terpenoid accumulation, a comprehensive experimental and theoretical approach will be employed to understand basic metabolism and improve final metabolite production metrics in non-model oleaginous microalgae. In this work, the microalga Neochloris oleoabundans will be grown under varying nitrogen and phosphorous nutrient levels, and sampled in time-series for transcriptomic and metabolomic analyses designed to characterize and optimize lipid and terpenoid formation. Steady state and dynamic stoichiometric metabolic modeling will be used to determine and predict systems-level responses to critical substrate uptake rates and stress-induced anabolic and catabolic gene activity as they pertain to maximized lipid and terpenoid accumulation. In parallel, a mutagenesis and high-resolution screening design will be applied to further improve non-model microalgae production metrics and, more importantly, provide a comparative basis across all three aims for intracellular metabolism representative of improved hydrocarbon production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microalgae biofuel production offers a sustainable solution for future energy demands. Microalgae have higher photosynthetic efficiency and convert atmospheric CO2 into fuel precursors such as lipids with a higher yield-to-cell ratio compared to other plants and energy crops considered for biofuel production. However, the increased production of precursor metabolites for biofuel (i.e., triacylglycerols) under nutrient stress is coupled with a decreased growth rate of microalgae. As such, understanding the biochemical pathways that are involved in halted growth can pave the way for more refined efforts to boost the production of lipid precursors for biofuel production.

This research project aims to obtain comprehensive information on the metabolite production capacity under nutrient stress conditions in a non-model microalgae, Ettlia oleabundans (formerly known as Neochloris oleoabundans). We developed a method that allows the extraction and analysis of a wide range of hydrophobic metabolites that are important for biofuel generation and photosynthesis. We then used this method to study the changes in metabolite levels under different nutrient conditions over time. We found that nitrogen deprivation significantly increased the levels of triacylglycerols. This increase peaked at late stationary phase. We also found that chlorophylls and certain structural lipids required for photosynthesis were depleted under the same conditions. We propose that these changes are related to the decreased microalgal photosynthetic efficiency during late stationary phase. Overall, our results provided key biochemical information on the lipid regulation and physiology of Ettlia oleabundans under nutrient stress.

We have obtained time series RNA-seq data for the nutrient deplete and replete conditions we used for metabolite analysis. We have completed the transcriptome assembly and annotated the transcripts using the National Center for Biotechnology Information’s (NCBI) database. Our current efforts include integration of metabolomics with transcriptomics to obtain a systems-level understanding of these regulations for sustained production of lipid precursors for biofuel production under times series exposure to nitrogen and phosphorus deplete and replete conditions.

We have also established a metabolic model of Ettlia oleoabundans based upon a constraint-based approach termed Flux Balance Analysis (FBA). We have established a proxy model (built from a eukaryotic base model and implementing metabolic steps associated with TAG biosynthesis) for Ettlia oleoabundans. We are currently testing these two models for flux rates and expect to complete the initial assessment of the models in conjunction with the experimental results thus far obtained.

We have included different levels of students in our studies for their academic training. This provided them with the opportunity to educate their peers, younger students, or both. For instance, seven Ph.D. students were trained over four years by the principal investigators and senior students working on the project. In addition, one M.S. student was trained by the principal investigators and is currently working at a biotechnology company. Two undergraduate researchers were also trained by a senior graduate student and the principal investigators. Through the joint research meetings between the teams, these students were exposed to concepts from metabolomics, transcriptomics and metabolic engineering.

Students at each academic level presented their work at national and international meetings. These meetings included the National American Chemical Society meetings and Undergraduate Research Symposium of the Western New York Section of the American Chemical Society.

We have hosted two high school teachers during two summer sessions. We assisted these teachers in developing experiments in our laboratory. The teachers then implemented these experiments in their classrooms in the upcoming school year. We also worked on preparing visual aids that are related to these experiments. Professional development opportunities provided by this activity benefitted both teachers and their students at different levels.
